metadata.title: Week 0: Environment Setup and Python Networking Basics
metadata.description: Formative assessment for Computer Networks prerequisites
metadata.author: ing. dr. Antonio Clim

learning_objectives.description: Apply port mapping between host and containers
Convert between bytes and strings in Python
Create and configure basic TCP sockets

questions.stem: What is the default port for the Portainer web interface?

feedback.correct: Well done! Portainer defaults to port 9000.
feedback.incorrect: Portainer uses port 9000 for HTTP access and 9443 for HTTPS.

questions.stem: Which command starts the Docker service in WSL2 (without systemd)?

options.text: docker start
systemctl start docker
sudo service docker start
wsl --start docker

feedback.correct: Correct! The service command works in WSL2 without systemd.
feedback.incorrect: In WSL2 without systemd enabled, services are managed with 'sudo service <name> start'.

questions.stem: What is the relationship between a Docker image and a container?

options.text: They are the same thing with different names
An image is a running instance of a container
A container is a running instance created from an image
Images are created by stopping containers

feedback.correct: Exactly! Think of images as templates and containers as instances.
feedback.incorrect: An image is a read-only template; a container is a runnable instance created from that image.

questions.stem: In the command 'docker run -p 8080:80 nginx', what does 8080 represent?

options.text: The container's internal port
The host machine's port
The maximum number of connections
The nginx version number

feedback.incorrect: The format is -p HOST:CONTAINER. Here, 8080 is the host port that maps to container port 80.

questions.stem: Why does 'curl localhost:9000' fail when run from inside an Alpine container, even though Portainer is running on the host at port 9000?

options.text: Alpine containers don't support the curl command
Portainer blocks access from other containers
localhost inside a container refers to that container, not the host
Port 9000 is reserved for system processes

feedback.correct: Exactly! Each container has its own localhost.
feedback.incorrect: Each container has its own network namespace. 'localhost' refers to the container's own loopback. Use 'host.docker.internal' to reach the host.

questions.stem: To convert the string 'Hello' to bytes in Python, use: 'Hello'.___('utf-8')
questions.hint: This method is the opposite of decode()

feedback.correct: Correct! encode() converts strings to bytes for network transmission.
feedback.incorrect: encode() converts str to bytes; decode() converts bytes to str.

questions.stem: To safely decode bytes that might contain invalid UTF-8 characters, use: data.decode('utf-8', errors='___')

feedback.correct: Well done! Using error handling prevents crashes on invalid data.
feedback.incorrect: Using errors='replace' substitutes invalid bytes with the Unicode replacement character, preventing exceptions.

questions.stem: To allow immediate port reuse after a server restart (avoiding 'Address already in use'), add before bind(): sock.setsockopt(socket.SOL_SOCKET, socket.___, 1)
questions.hint: This socket option allows reusing the address

feedback.correct: Correct! SO_REUSEADDR is essential for development servers.
feedback.incorrect: SO_REUSEADDR allows binding to a port in TIME_WAIT state, which is useful during development.

questions.stem: Which struct format string correctly packs a port number (2 bytes) in network byte order (big-endian)?

options.text: struct.pack('H', port)
struct.pack('!H', port)
struct.pack('h', port)
struct.pack('I', port)

feedback.correct: Excellent! Always use '!' for network protocols.
feedback.incorrect: The '!' prefix specifies network byte order (big-endian). 'H' is an unsigned short (2 bytes).

questions.stem: After running 'docker stop mycontainer', what happens to the container and its data?

options.text: The container and all its data are permanently deleted
The container enters 'Exited' state; data is preserved
Data is automatically backed up to a volume
The container is removed but volumes are kept

feedback.correct: Correct! stop preserves the container; rm removes it.
feedback.incorrect: docker stop gracefully stops a container but preserves it and its data. Use 'docker rm' to remove.
